message_1:
Suppose the heights and weights of 10 people are recorded in the following table:

| Person | Height (inches) | Weight (pounds) |
| ------ | -------------- | --------------- |
| 1      | 68             | 165             |
| 2      | 71             | 201             |
| 3      | 61             | 142             |
| 4      | 74             | 210             |
| 5      | 65             | 167             |
| 6      | 63             | 151             |
| 7      | 68             | 170             |
| 8      | 72             | 183             |
| 9      | 60             | 139             |
| 10     | 67             | 166             |

Use a correlation analysis to determine the strength and direction of the relationship between height and weight.
message_2:
To determine the strength and direction of the relationship between height and weight, we will calculate the correlation coefficient (r). First, we need to find the mean of both height and weight, and then calculate the deviations from the mean for each data point. Finally, we will use the formula for the correlation coefficient:

r = Σ[(xi - x_mean)(yi - y_mean)] / sqrt(Σ(xi - x_mean)^2 * Σ(yi - y_mean)^2)

Step 1: Calculate the mean of height and weight
Height mean (x_mean) = (68 + 71 + 61 + 74 + 65 + 63 + 68 + 72 + 60 + 67) / 10 = 669 / 10 = 66.9 inches
Weight mean (y_mean) = (165 + 201 + 142 + 210 + 167 + 151 + 170 + 183 + 139 + 166) / 10 = 1694 / 10 = 169.4 pounds

Step 2: Calculate the deviations from the mean for each data point
| Person | Height Deviation (xi - x_mean) | Weight Deviation (yi - y_mean) |
| ------ | ------------------------------ | ------------------------------ |
| 1      | 68 - 66.9 = 1.1                | 165 - 169.4 = -4.4             |
| 2      | 71 - 66.9 = 4.1                | 201 - 169.4 = 31.6             |
| 3      | 61 - 66.9 = -5.9               | 142 - 169.4 = -27.4            |
| 4      | 74 - 66.9 = 7.1                | 210 - 169.4 = 40.6             |
| 5      | 65 - 66.9 = -1.9               | 167 - 169.4 = -2.4             |
| 6      | 63 - 66.9 = -3.9               | 151 - 169.4 = -18.4            |
| 7      | 68 - 66.9 = 1.1                | 170 - 169.4 = 0.6              |
| 8      | 72 - 66.9 = 5.1                | 183 - 169.4 = 13.6             |
| 9      | 60 - 66.9 = -6.9               | 139 - 169.4 = -30.4            |
| 10     | 67 - 66.9 = 0.1                | 166 - 169.4 = -3.4             |

Step 3: Calculate the correlation coefficient (r)
r = Σ[(xi - x_mean)(yi - y_mean)] / sqrt(Σ(xi - x_mean)^2 * Σ(yi - y_mean)^2)

Numerator = Σ[(xi - x_mean)(yi - y_mean)] = (1.1 * -4.4) + (4.1 * 31.6) + (-5.9 * -27.4) + (7.1 * 40.6) + (-1.9 * -2.4) + (-3.9 * -18.4) + (1.1 * 0.6) + (5.1 * 13.6) + (-6.9 * -30.4) + (0.1 * -3.4) = -4.84 + 129.56 + 161.66 + 288.06 + 4.56 + 71.76 + 0.66 + 69.36 + 209.56 - 0.34 = 900.4

Denominator = sqrt(Σ(xi - x_mean)^2 * Σ(yi - y_mean)^2) = sqrt((1.1^2 + 4.1^2 + -5.9^2 + 7.1^2 + -1.9^2 + -3.9^2 + 1.1^2 + 5.1^2 + -6.9^2 + 0.1^2) * (-4.4^2 + 31.6^2 + -27.4^2 + 40.6^2 + -2.4^2 + -18.4^2 + 0.6^2 + 13.6^2 + -30.4^2 + -3.4^2)) = sqrt(262.87 * 3895.12) = sqrt(1023773.56) = 1011.8

r = 900.4 / 1011.8 = 0.89

The correlation coefficient (r) is 0.89, which indicates a strong positive relationship between height and weight. This means that as height increases, weight also tends to increase.
